title: How to Keep Your Over Easy Eggs from Getting Firm

steps.headline: Insert your toast in the toaster or bacon on the griddle, if you plan to have other ingredients in your breakfast.
steps.description: Eggs over-easy take no more than 5 minutes, and waiting too long can result in firm yolks.

steps.headline: Place a cast-iron skillet or non-stick skillet on a burner of approximately the same size.
steps.description: Turn the heat to medium-low. You want to avoid a skillet that is too hot because it will cook the eggs unevenly.

steps.headline: Put 1 tbsp.
steps.description: (14 g) of unsalted butter into the cast-iron skillet after it is heated. If you are using a non-stick skillet, place the 1 tbsp. (14 g) of unsalted butter into the skillet while it heats up. You can also use 1 tbsp. (13.5 g) of olive oil or a mixture of olive oil and butter, depending upon the flavor you prefer for your eggs.

steps.headline: Wait for the butter to foam and then stop foaming before you break your egg.
steps.description: Swirl the butter so that it covers the bottom of your skillet.

steps.headline: Crack an egg on a flat surface, such as a counter.
Cover the skillet with a lid.
steps.description: This will help to trap the heat in and cook all parts of the egg. There are 3 parts of the egg that you need to cook in this process: the yolk, the inner white around the yolk and the outer white. The outer white cooks the fastest, but the inner white takes a while to set.

steps.headline: Leave the egg unchecked for 1 minute.
steps.description: It should take 1 to 1.5 minutes for the inner white of the egg to set. Leave the egg until the inner white turns milky and is no longer clear. If you are cooking 2 eggs, it is likely to take at least 1.5 minutes for the inner white to set on the first side and 35 seconds for the eggs to cook on the other side when flipped.

steps.headline: Place a thin pancake turner under the egg when it is ready to flip.
steps.description: Ensure the turner is completely underneath. Flip it quickly but gently, so that you don't break the yolk.

steps.headline: Cover the skillet with the lid.
steps.description: Turn off the heat on your stove. The remaining heat will cook the egg.

steps.headline: Leave the egg on this side for 20 to 30 seconds.
steps.description: Flip the egg again and remove the skillet from heat.

steps.headline: Place the egg on top of toast or a plate.

text:
Insert your toast in the toaster or bacon on the griddle, if you plan to have other ingredients in your breakfast. Eggs over-easy take no more than 5 minutes, and waiting too long can result in firm yolks. Place a cast-iron skillet or non-stick skillet on a burner of approximately the same size. Turn the heat to medium-low. You want to avoid a skillet that is too hot because it will cook the eggs unevenly. Put 1 tbsp. (14 g) of unsalted butter into the cast-iron skillet after it is heated. If you are using a non-stick skillet, place the 1 tbsp. (14 g) of unsalted butter into the skillet while it heats up. You can also use 1 tbsp. (13.5 g) of olive oil or a mixture of olive oil and butter, depending upon the flavor you prefer for your eggs. Wait for the butter to foam and then stop foaming before you break your egg. Swirl the butter so that it covers the bottom of your skillet. Crack an egg on a flat surface, such as a counter. You are less likely to get shells in your fried egg if you crack it on a flat surface. Open the eggshell gently over your buttered skillet. If you often find egg shells in your cracked eggs, crack the egg into a bowl first and remove the shells. You can pour the egg from the bowl into your skillet. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Keep-Your-Over-Easy-Eggs-from-Getting-Firm-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-460px-Keep-Your-Over-Easy-Eggs-from-Getting-Firm-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/1/11/Keep-Your-Over-Easy-Eggs-from-Getting-Firm-Step-5Bullet1.jpg/v4-760px-Keep-Your-Over-Easy-Eggs-from-Getting-Firm-Step-5Bullet1.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} If the egg sizzles when it hits the surface of the pan, it is too hot. Turn the heat down to avoid overcooking. If you are cooking 2 eggs, try to place them close together so that you can flip them together. {"smallUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/49/Keep-Your-Over-Easy-Eggs-from-Getting-Firm-Step-5Bullet3.jpg/v4-460px-Keep-Your-Over-Easy-Eggs-from-Getting-Firm-Step-5Bullet3.jpg","bigUrl":"https://www.wikihow.com/images/thumb/4/49/Keep-Your-Over-Easy-Eggs-from-Getting-Firm-Step-5Bullet3.jpg/v4-760px-Keep-Your-Over-Easy-Eggs-from-Getting-Firm-Step-5Bullet3.jpg","smallWidth":460,"smallHeight":345,"bigWidth":760,"bigHeight":570,"licensing":"

License: Creative Commons


"} Cover the skillet with a lid. This will help to trap the heat in and cook all parts of the egg. There are 3 parts of the egg that you need to cook in this process: the yolk, the inner white around the yolk and the outer white. The outer white cooks the fastest, but the inner white takes a while to set. Leave the egg unchecked for 1 minute. It should take 1 to 1.5 minutes for the inner white of the egg to set. Leave the egg until the inner white turns milky and is no longer clear. If you are cooking 2 eggs, it is likely to take at least 1.5 minutes for the inner white to set on the first side and 35 seconds for the eggs to cook on the other side when flipped. Place a thin pancake turner under the egg when it is ready to flip. Ensure the turner is completely underneath. Flip it quickly but gently, so that you don't break the yolk. Cover the skillet with the lid. Turn off the heat on your stove. The remaining heat will cook the egg. Leave the egg on this side for 20 to 30 seconds. Flip the egg again and remove the skillet from heat. Place the egg on top of toast or a plate. Season with salt and pepper.
